author: Graham Rayman
title: Rikers inmate gets sentenced to 8 years for assaulting officers
text:
Rikers inmate gets sentenced to 8 years for assaulting correction officers Rikers inmate gets sentenced to 8 years for assaulting officers NEW YORK DAILY NEWS   8:52 PM 
A Bronx judge ordered a Rikers Island inmate responsible for a bloody spree of assaults on correction officers and slashings to serve eight years in prison, officials said Monday. 
Bronx District Attorney Darcel Clark said Carl Henegain, 20, punched a jail captain and a correction officer in separate incidents, and stormed into another inmate’s cell and slashed him twice in the face. The attacks happened at two different Rikers jails in 2015 and 2016. 
The correction officer he punched was giving him water at the time, officials said. He also allegedly splashed an officer with an unknown substance. 
“This defendant was notorious for his crime spree on Rikers Island,” Clark said. “I hope this serves as a deterrent and reinforces our message that crimes committed in the city’s jails will have serious consequences.” 
Suspect in 2005 NYC beheading says 'I'm not a monster' 
Henegain pleaded guilty to the charges on Feb. 2. He also pleaded guilty to promoting prison contraband for being found with sharp metal objects, and harassment for several other minor assaults. 
Henegain has been jailed at Rikers Island since June 23, 2014, when he was charged with second-degree attempted murder. 
He was acquitted of that charge, but convicted of False Personation – a B misdemeanor which carried a 60-day sentence. 
“These sentences stand as a warning: If you attack individuals in our custody or members of our staff, you will suffer certain consequences,” Correction Commissioner Joseph Ponte said. 
More victims likely tied to NYC man charged with murder 
Correction Officers' Benevolent Association President Elias Husamudeen said the sentence was another sign that people who committ crimes in jail will no longer go unpunished. 
"The COBA has for years called for prosecutors to serve swift justice to assaultive inmates who repeatedly commit criminal acts against our officers,” he said. 
“Today, justice is finally being served to this inmate and his consecutive sentencing totaling more than eight years should serve as a stark reminder to other inmates that they will do serious time for their crimes committed behind bars.” Join the Conversation:
